unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Significance Test: U.S. Versus China
question_text:
A randomized experiment was performed to determine whether the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. is different than the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China.
Which of the following best describes the conclusion that can be drawn?
Which of the following best describes the conclusion that can be drawn?
tables:
U.S.A. Manufactured CarsChina Manufactured Cars
Average$21.435$$25.578$
Standard Deviation$6.635$$7.413$
Number of cars$200$$85$

choices.text: There is evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p<0.01$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p<0.01$.

There is evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $0.01 < p < 0.05$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $0.01 < p < 0.05$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p>0.05$.

solution:
First, let us define the parameters and state the null and alternative hypotheses:

μU= average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A.
μC= average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China
H0:μU=μC
Ha:μU≠μC

The alternative hypothesis is not equal as we are looking to prove the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured cars in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China is different.

Next, let us find the P-value. This can be done one of two ways: calculator based or Student's t-test.

Method 1: Using a calculator

On your TI-84 or TI-83 press Stat.
Go over to Test and hit enter.
The type of test we are doing is a 2-Sample T-test for means since we have two independent samples and the standard deviation of the population is unknown making it a t-test.
Select #4
from the list of tests.
Select the Stats side and not the data side since we have the statistical values.
Enter the first area data in first followed by the second area. Your calculator screen should like something like this:



We selected the not equal to sign (≠
) because that is the sign of the alternative hypothesis.
It is not pooled because the standard errors are not equal.

Once you have all your information entered into the calculator scroll down to the(still in the test part) Calculate button and press enter. Your calculator screen should like this:



From this, we can see the P-value is approximately 0
.

We can eliminate Choices 'C', 'D', and 'E'.

Choice 'B' is incorrect since even though our p-value is less than 0.01
we would reject the null hypothesis and take the alternative hypothesis which states there is a significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured cars in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China.

Choice 'A' is correct since our p-value is less than 0.01
. We would reject the null hypothesis and take the alternative hypothesis which states there is a significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured cars in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China.

This method requires a lot of work! It is better to use the functions of the graphing calculator to save time on the exam.
